title: Psalms Chapter 35 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 35 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 35 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 35.

questions.question: Who is asked to plead the cause in Psalms 35:1?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:1 states, 'Plead my cause, O LORD, with them that strive with me,' showing that David asks the LORD to plead his cause.

questions.question: According to Psalms 35:2, what should be taken hold of for help?
questions.correctAnswer: Shield and buckler
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:2 says, 'Take hold of shield and buckler, and stand up for mine help,' indicating these are the items to be taken.

questions.question: What does David ask God to do against those who persecute him, according to Psalms 35:3?
options: Draw out the spear and stop the way
questions.correctAnswer: Draw out the spear and stop the way
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:3 instructs God to 'Draw out also the spear, and stop the way against them that persecute me.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 35:9: 'And my soul shall be joyful in the ______:'
questions.correctAnswer: LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:9 states, 'And my soul shall be joyful in the LORD,' highlighting where the joy is found.

questions.question: What does Psalms 35:10 say all David’s bones will say?
options: LORD, who is like unto thee
questions.correctAnswer: LORD, who is like unto thee
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:10 says, 'All my bones shall say, LORD, who is like unto thee,' praising God’s uniqueness.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 35:11, false witnesses rose up and laid charges that David knew not.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:11 states, 'False witnesses did rise up; they laid to my charge things that I knew not.'

questions.question: How did David behave towards those who were sick, according to Psalms 35:13?
options: Wore sackcloth and humbled his soul with fasting
questions.correctAnswer: Wore sackcloth and humbled his soul with fasting
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:13 says, 'my clothing was sackcloth: I humbled my soul with fasting;' describing David's compassion.

questions.question: What did David do as though an enemy had been his friend or brother, as stated in Psalms 35:14?
options: Bowed down heavily as one that mourneth for his mother
questions.correctAnswer: Bowed down heavily as one that mourneth for his mother
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:14 says, 'I behaved myself as though he had been my friend or brother: I bowed down heavily, as one that mourneth for his mother.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 35:15, how did David's adversaries respond to his adversity?
options: They rejoiced and gathered against him
They repented and asked for forgiveness
questions.correctAnswer: They rejoiced and gathered against him
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:15 states, 'But in mine adversity they rejoiced, and gathered themselves together,' showing their hostile response.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 35:17 asks the Lord to rescue David's soul from destruction and his darling from lions.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:17 says, 'rescue my soul from their destructions, my darling from the lions,' which is a plea for deliverance.

questions.question: What will David do in the great congregation according to Psalms 35:18?
options: Give thanks and praise the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Give thanks and praise the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:18 states, 'I will give thee thanks in the great congregation: I will praise thee among much people.'

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 35:20, David's enemies speak peace and goodwill towards him.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:20 states, 'For they speak not peace: but they devise deceitful matters against them that are quiet in the land.'

questions.question: What did David ask the LORD not to do in Psalms 35:22?
options: Keep silence and be far from him
questions.correctAnswer: Keep silence and be far from him
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:22 says, 'This thou hast seen, O LORD: keep not silence: O Lord, be not far from me.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 35:24, how does David want to be judged?
questions.correctAnswer: According to God's righteousness
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:24 states, 'Judge me, O LORD my God, according to thy righteousness.'

questions.question: What does David want his enemies to be clothed with, according to Psalms 35:26?
questions.correctAnswer: Shame and dishonour
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:26 says, 'let them be clothed with shame and dishonour that magnify themselves against me.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 35 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 35 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is facing false accusations at work. Based on Psalms 35, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God during trials?
options: God fights for those who rely on Him and delivers them from their enemies
One should always retaliate immediately against false accusers
Trust in human strength to overcome adversity
Ignore the situation and avoid prayer
questions.correctAnswer: God fights for those who rely on Him and delivers them from their enemies
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:1-3 shows David asking God to fight against those who fight him and to protect him. Verses 9-10 express joy in God's salvation and His deliverance of the needy from the strong.

questions.question: How does Psalms 35 teach about humility and compassion towards others who suffer, even when we are mistreated?
options: We should mourn with those who are sick and humble ourselves in fasting and prayer
We should ignore others' suffering to focus on our own pain
We should rejoice when our enemies suffer
We should seek revenge for every wrong
questions.correctAnswer: We should mourn with those who are sick and humble ourselves in fasting and prayer
questions.explanation: In Psalms 35:13-14, David describes how he humbled himself with fasting and mourned as if for a close friend or family member, showing compassion despite his own adversity.

questions.question: What does Psalms 35:10 teach us about God's character and His care for the vulnerable?
options: The LORD delivers the poor and needy from those too strong for them
God favors only the wealthy and powerful
God is indifferent to the plight of the poor
Strength and power are the ultimate means of justice
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD delivers the poor and needy from those too strong for them
questions.explanation: Verse 10 praises God for delivering the poor and needy from the oppressors, highlighting His righteousness and care for the vulnerable.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with bitterness towards those who mock them. Based on Psalms 35, what is a godly response?
options: Trust God to judge justly and refrain from rejoicing over enemies
Retaliate quickly and mock them back
Harbor anger and refuse to pray
Ignore God's justice and seek human revenge
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to judge justly and refrain from rejoicing over enemies
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:19-26 teaches not to let enemies rejoice wrongfully, but to trust God’s righteous judgment and to seek His intervention rather than personal revenge.

questions.question: What spiritual discipline does David mention in Psalms 35 that helped him in times of adversity?
questions.correctAnswer: Fasting and prayer
questions.explanation: In Psalms 35:13, David humbles himself with fasting and prayer during his adversities, showing reliance on God through spiritual discipline.

questions.question: How does Psalms 35 encourage believers to respond in fellowship when God delivers them?
options: Give thanks and praise God publicly among many people
Keep deliverance private and avoid public worship
questions.correctAnswer: Give thanks and praise God publicly among many people
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:18 states the intention to thank and praise God in the great congregation, encouraging public worship and testimony.

questions.question: What lesson about integrity and honesty can we learn from Psalms 35 regarding false accusations?
options: Maintain innocence and trust God to reveal the truth
questions.correctAnswer: Maintain innocence and trust God to reveal the truth
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:11-12 describe false witnesses accusing David falsely, yet he remains faithful and trusts God to judge rightly (verses 22-24).

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 35, believers should seek God's help urgently when facing persecution and opposition.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:22-23 show David asking God not to be silent and to awake for his judgment, indicating urgency in seeking God's help.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 35 encourages believers to rejoice in their enemies' misfortune without praying for justice.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:26-27 instruct that those who rejoice over others' harm should be ashamed, and believers should instead praise God for justice and prosperity, not rejoice in enemies’ misfortune.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 35:3 says, 'Draw out also the spear, and stop the way against them that ______ me.'
questions.correctAnswer: persecute
questions.explanation: Verse 3 instructs God to stop the way against those who persecute David, demonstrating a plea for divine protection.

questions.question: How does Psalms 35 describe God's protection for the believer under attack?
options: God uses His angel to chase and persecute the enemies
The believer must rely only on physical weapons
God encourages the believer to avoid confrontation
questions.correctAnswer: God uses His angel to chase and persecute the enemies
questions.explanation: Verses 5-6 describe God’s angel chasing the enemies and persecuting them, showing divine intervention on behalf of the believer.

questions.question: In Psalms 35, what attitude does David have towards God amidst his suffering?
options: Joy and praise for God's salvation
questions.correctAnswer: Joy and praise for God's salvation
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:9-10 express David's joy and praise for God's salvation and deliverance even amid trials.

questions.question: What does Psalms 35 teach about praying for vindication and justice?
options: Ask God to judge according to righteousness and not let enemies rejoice
Pray for personal revenge regardless of righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: Ask God to judge according to righteousness and not let enemies rejoice
questions.explanation: Verses 23-24 ask God to awaken for judgment and to judge according to righteousness, preventing enemies from rejoicing unjustly.

questions.question: What practical application about perseverance can be drawn from David’s attitude in Psalms 35?
options: Continue to trust and praise God despite ongoing opposition
questions.correctAnswer: Continue to trust and praise God despite ongoing opposition
questions.explanation: David repeatedly prays for deliverance but also commits to praising God continually (verse 28) regardless of his trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 35 guide believers in dealing with hypocritical mockers?
options: Trust God to rescue from their attacks and not retaliate in kind
Ignore God's help and seek revenge
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to rescue from their attacks and not retaliate in kind
questions.explanation: Verse 17 requests God’s rescue from mockers and lions, showing dependence on God’s protection rather than personal retaliation.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 35 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 35.

questions.question: In Psalms 35:1, David asks the LORD to plead his cause against whom?
questions.correctAnswer: Those who strive with him
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:1 explicitly states, 'Plead my cause, O LORD, with them that strive with me,' indicating David's request for God's intervention against his adversaries.

questions.question: What weapon imagery does David use in Psalms 35:2-3 to describe God's protection?
questions.correctAnswer: Shield, buckler, spear
questions.explanation: Verses 2 and 3 mention 'Take hold of shield and buckler,' and 'Draw out also the spear,' showing David's invocation of divine military protection imagery.

questions.question: What is the repeated literary device used in Psalms 35:4-6 when describing the fate of David's enemies?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Verses 4 to 6 display parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device where lines mirror each other in structure and meaning, e.g., 'Let them be confounded and put to shame' parallels 'Let them be as chaff before the wind.'

questions.question: In Psalms 35:5-6, who is described as pursuing and persecuting David's enemies?
questions.correctAnswer: The angel of the LORD
questions.explanation: Both verses 5 and 6 mention 'the angel of the LORD' as the pursuer of David's enemies, suggesting divine agency in their destruction.

questions.question: What Hebrew term conceptually underlies the phrase 'Let them be as chaff before the wind' in Psalms 35:5, and what does it signify?
questions.correctAnswer: Chaff, signifying uselessness and instability
questions.explanation: The phrase 'as chaff before the wind' uses 'chaff,' which in Hebrew poetry symbolizes something light, worthless, and easily scattered, indicating the futility of the enemies' efforts (Psalms 35:5).

questions.question: How does Psalms 35:7-8 illustrate the theme of unjust persecution, and what cultural context does it reflect?
options: Enemies secretly setting traps without cause, reflecting ancient Near Eastern legal and social conflicts
Enemies openly declaring war, reflecting military customs
Enemies making public accusations, reflecting Israelite court practices
Enemies engaging in ritual curses, reflecting pagan rites
questions.correctAnswer: Enemies secretly setting traps without cause, reflecting ancient Near Eastern legal and social conflicts
questions.explanation: Verses 7 and 8 describe enemies hiding nets and pits to trap David without cause, a metaphor for deceitful plots common in the ancient Near East's legal and social struggles.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage echoes the theme of unjust suffering and false witnesses seen in Psalms 35:11-12?
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 2:12-23 discusses unjust suffering and false accusations, paralleling Psalms 35:11-12 where false witnesses rise against David and reward evil for good.

questions.question: In Psalms 35:13-14, David's behavior toward his adversaries is described. Which literary device is at work when he says he behaved 'as though he had been my friend or brother'?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: The phrase 'as though he had been my friend or brother' is a simile, a direct comparison using 'as' to highlight David's unexpected kindness toward enemies (Psalms 35:14).

questions.question: Psalms 35:17 uses the metaphor 'my darling from the lions.' What does this metaphor likely signify in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: Rescue from powerful and dangerous enemies
Protection from wild animals in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: Rescue from powerful and dangerous enemies
questions.explanation: The 'lions' metaphorically represent fierce enemies or dangers, common in ancient Near East imagery, so David is asking God to rescue him from threatening adversaries (Psalms 35:17).

questions.question: True or False: In Psalms 35:18, David promises to praise God only in private prayer settings.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:18 states David will give thanks 'in the great congregation' and 'among much people,' indicating public praise rather than private only.

questions.question: Which theme in Psalms 35:19-21 reflects the social dangers of deceit and false celebration by enemies?
options: Deceitful joy over the misfortune of the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: Deceitful joy over the misfortune of the righteous
questions.explanation: Verses 19-21 describe enemies rejoicing wrongfully and speaking deceit, emphasizing the theme of malicious joy over David's suffering.

questions.question: In Psalms 35:22-23, David petitions God to 'stir up thyself' and 'awake to my judgment.' This plea is an example of what type of prayer commonly found in Hebrew poetry?
questions.correctAnswer: Imprecatory prayer
questions.explanation: David's call for God to act against his enemies is characteristic of imprecatory prayers, which ask for divine justice and intervention (Psalms 35:22-23).

questions.question: How does the theme of divine justice in Psalms 35:24-26 connect to the broader biblical concept of righteousness?
options: God judges according to righteousness and shames the proud
Human kings execute justice without God's involvement
Righteousness is a personal feeling unrelated to justice
Justice is solely retributive without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: God judges according to righteousness and shames the proud
questions.explanation: Verses 24-26 emphasize God's righteous judgment and the shame of those who rejoice at the sufferings of the innocent, aligning with the biblical theme of divine justice.

questions.question: The concluding verses Psalms 35:27-28 focus on which aspect of God's relationship with the psalmist?
options: God's pleasure in the prosperity of His servant and continual praise
God's silence in times of suffering
God's judgment limited to the nation of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: God's pleasure in the prosperity of His servant and continual praise
questions.explanation: Verses 27-28 highlight that God delights in the prosperity of His servant and that the psalmist will continually praise God's righteousness and greatness.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the authorial intent behind Psalms 35?
options: To seek divine justice against unjust enemies and express trust in God's salvation
To recount historical battles fought by David
To teach sacrificial rituals for the temple
To prophesy the coming of the Messiah
questions.correctAnswer: To seek divine justice against unjust enemies and express trust in God's salvation
questions.explanation: The psalm is a plea for God's intervention against adversaries and a declaration of faith in divine deliverance, reflecting David's intent (Psalms 35:1-28).

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 35 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 35 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Psalms 35, how does David describe God's role in his conflict against his adversaries?
options: As a warrior who fights on his behalf
questions.correctAnswer: As a warrior who fights on his behalf
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:1-3 depicts God as actively fighting against David's enemies, akin to a warrior defending His servant. This aligns with Exodus 15:3 where God is described as a man of war, and Romans 8:31 which says God fights for those who love Him.

questions.question: What metaphor does David use to describe the fate of his enemies in Psalms 35:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Like chaff before the wind
questions.explanation: David uses the metaphor of enemies being like chaff before the wind, suggesting their vulnerability and ultimate defeat (Psalms 35:5). This imagery is consistent with Isaiah 17:13 and Matthew 3:12 where chaff represents what is worthless and easily dispersed.

questions.question: According to Psalms 35:10, what attribute of God is emphasized through His deliverance of the poor and needy?
questions.correctAnswer: His justice and compassion
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:10 highlights God's justice and compassion in delivering the poor and needy from oppression. This reflects God's character seen in Proverbs 31:8-9 and Luke 4:18-19, where God advocates for the marginalized and oppressed.

questions.question: In Psalms 35:11-12, David describes the behavior of his adversaries as involving false witnesses. What theological issue does this reveal?
options: The problem of human sinfulness and injustice
questions.correctAnswer: The problem of human sinfulness and injustice
questions.explanation: David’s experience with false witnesses (Psalms 35:11-12) reveals the biblical reality of human sinfulness and injustice, reflecting themes found in Exodus 23:1 and Matthew 26:60 where false testimony is condemned.

questions.question: What is the significance of David's fasting and sackcloth in Psalms 35:13 in relation to his prayer life?
options: It expresses deep humility and earnest intercession
It signifies his rejection of God
It shows his physical weakness only
It is a sign of joy and celebration
questions.correctAnswer: It expresses deep humility and earnest intercession
questions.explanation: David’s fasting and wearing sackcloth (Psalms 35:13) signify humility and earnest prayer, a biblical pattern for seeking God’s intervention (Joel 2:12-13, Daniel 9:3, and Jonah 3:5-9).

questions.question: In Psalms 35:17, David calls on the Lord to rescue his soul from 'lions.' What does this metaphor signify in biblical theology?
questions.correctAnswer: Dangerous enemies or destructive forces
questions.explanation: The 'lions' in Psalms 35:17 symbolize threatening enemies or destructive spiritual forces, consistent with biblical symbolism in 1 Peter 5:8 and Hosea 5:14 where lions represent danger and evil.

questions.question: How does Psalms 35:18 reflect the eschatological hope and corporate worship in the life of the believer?
options: By promising public thanksgiving and praise in the congregation
By highlighting individual success apart from community
questions.correctAnswer: By promising public thanksgiving and praise in the congregation
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:18 emphasizes thanksgiving in the great congregation, reflecting the biblical theme of communal worship and eschatological hope seen in Hebrews 12:28 and Revelation 7:9-10.

questions.question: What does David request God to do in Psalms 35:23-24, and how does this relate to the doctrine of divine justice?
options: Stir up Himself and judge according to righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: Stir up Himself and judge according to righteousness
questions.explanation: David’s plea in Psalms 35:23-24 for God to act and judge righteously highlights the biblical doctrine of divine justice, which is impartial and active, as affirmed in Psalm 9:7-8 and Romans 2:5-6.

questions.question: In Psalms 35:26, what consequence does David wish upon those who rejoice at his misfortune?
questions.correctAnswer: Shame and confusion
questions.explanation: David desires shame and confusion upon those who take pleasure in his hurt (Psalms 35:26), consistent with biblical teaching on the fate of the wicked seen in Proverbs 3:34 and Romans 12:19.

questions.question: According to Psalms 35:27, what is the appropriate response of those who favor David’s righteous cause?
options: Shout for joy and continually magnify the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Shout for joy and continually magnify the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:27 calls for joyful praise and continuous glorification of the LORD by those who support righteousness, reflecting biblical principles found in Psalm 149:6-9 and Philippians 4:4.

questions.question: What does the repeated plea for God not to let enemies rejoice 'wrongfully' in Psalms 35:19 suggest about God's justice?
options: God protects the righteous from unjust triumph of wickedness
God allows evil to triumph permanently
questions.correctAnswer: God protects the righteous from unjust triumph of wickedness
questions.explanation: David’s plea in Psalms 35:19 highlights God’s role in protecting the righteous from unjust victory by the wicked, consistent with Psalms 37:1-2 and Romans 12:19 where God’s justice ultimately prevails.

questions.question: How does Psalms 35:28 express the ongoing role of the believer’s testimony in glorifying God?
options: The believer’s tongue speaks of God's righteousness and praise all day long
The believer remains silent about God’s acts
The believer only praises God in times of joy
The believer focuses on earthly achievements
questions.correctAnswer: The believer’s tongue speaks of God's righteousness and praise all day long
questions.explanation: Psalms 35:28 reveals that continual testimony about God's righteousness is integral to the believer's life, paralleling 1 Corinthians 10:31 and Hebrews 13:15 on glorifying God continuously.

questions.question: What does David mean by saying his 'prayer returned into mine own bosom' in Psalms 35:13?
options: His prayers seemed unanswered or absorbed deeply within
questions.correctAnswer: His prayers seemed unanswered or absorbed deeply within
questions.explanation: The phrase in Psalms 35:13 suggests a sense of unanswered prayer or internalized lament, reflecting the biblical reality of waiting on God as seen in Lamentations 3:24 and Habakkuk 2:1.

questions.question: In Psalms 35:7-8, what theological truth is underscored by the enemies' traps catching themselves?
options: God's justice causes the wicked to fall by their own schemes
All plans succeed regardless of morality
questions.correctAnswer: God's justice causes the wicked to fall by their own schemes
questions.explanation: The self-destructive nature of the enemies' traps (Psalms 35:7-8) illustrates divine justice where God causes the wicked to be ensnared by their own devices, consistent with Proverbs 26:27 and 2 Timothy 3:13.

questions.question: How does David’s treatment of his adversaries in Psalms 35:14 illustrate Christian ethics regarding enemies?
options: He behaves as if they were friends or brothers
questions.correctAnswer: He behaves as if they were friends or brothers
questions.explanation: David acting as if enemies were friends (Psalms 35:14) reflects Christ’s teaching to love enemies and pray for those who persecute you (Matthew 5:44, Romans 12:20).
